p.s: The given text scene takes part in the fourth scene of the play Disgraced, Scene 4.
After the divorce of the two main characters Emily and Amir, Emily and Amir's nephew Abe came to visit because of an urgent situation.
Abe, who in contrast to the beginning of the play is now again fully commited to the Islam, went to a coffeshopcoffeeshop with one of his muslimMuslim friends.
They then started an argument about their opinion on Al-Quaida, a terroristic group of the Islam.
After they stated that America and their society is the origin of the group the worker eventually calls the police and Abe is being arrested.
Talking to his uncle he admits, that they brought up his immigration status which is now up to renewal (cf. l. 1-3).
But instead of being serious about this problem, he actually laughed when he talked to the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation.
Because Amir is speechless because of his nephew attitude, Abe explains that they deliberately look for people like him, whoswhose immigration status is vulnerable (l. 10f.).
They use this as a methodemethod to make those immigrant work for them (cf. l. 11).
Even though he got himself in that situation Abe is scared his mother finds out as she's probably going to freak out (l. 16).
But because Amir seems sceptical throughout their whole conversation.
Amir doesn't feel understood and asks him what he'd do, if the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation asks him to work for them (cf. l. 28).
Even though Amir doesn't seem to understand his nephew and his acts, he provides solutions and ideas to support him.
To help him on a legal base, he decides to call Ken, the lawyer of Imam Fareed who played a part earlier in the play (cf. l. 19f.).
Moreover Amir also gives personal advice to Abe.
He highlights that Abe has to change his behaviour in order to fit in society of America.
He states his disbelief about Abe laughing at the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation and amplifies that this behaviour was stupid.
Additionally, he tries to provide another point of view for Abe, as this world isn't neutral (l. 21) and he as an immigrant especially has to give a positive picture of his behaviour.
He doesn't answer Abe's question about the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation, as he doesn't want to.
Probably because he is focused on supporting his nephew.
He also critizises his nephew though.
He highlights that he needs to show that he is on the side of the authorities even though he isn't.
Otherwise he won't win the case.
